responses.content_en: Most probably it is a case of friction blisters. Friction blisters are caused due to excessive friction between the skin and a surface. Examples of surfaces that could cause friction blisters include rough clothing, bed linens, or towels. They can also be caused by repetitive rubbing of the same area, such as when a person with hairy arms brushes his or her arms against a rough surface. Blisters usually heal on their own in a few weeks, but there are ways you can speed up the healing process. Apply a moisturizing cream containing aloe vera, petroleum jelly or shea butter. Wear loose cotton clothing. Avoid friction by wearing gloves when doing household chores.

It is a case of folliculitis, which is inflammation of the hair follicles. You can get folliculitis from folliculitis of the hair follicles, which is often caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi. They can also be caused by hair removal, such as when you get a bikini line or back acne, or weight gain. The most common cause of folliculitis is a bacterial infection of the hair follicle, usually Staphylococcus aureus. This can happen after shaving, plucking, or other hair removal procedures. You can get folliculitis from these actions too. Other causes of folliculitis include: wearing tight clothing or shoes, using harsh chemicals on your skin, such as detergents and solvents, swimming in pools with contaminated water, and certain medications. To treat folliculitis, you need to identify the cause. If it is caused by bacteria, you need to clean the area and take antibiotics to kill the bacteria. If it is caused by a virus or a fungus, you need to get rid of the infected hair and use a topical antifungal to help the skin heal. You can also use a topical antibiotic to help the skin heal. To prevent future infections, you should clean the area and use a topical antibiotic or antifungal after shaving, plucking, or other hair removal procedures. You can also use a topical antibiotic to help the skin heal. To prevent future infections, you should keep the area clean and dry. Use a topical antibiotic to help the skin heal.

Hyperpigmentation is a common cause of discoloration of the skin. It occurs when certain areas of the skin produce too much melanin, the pigment that gives skin its color. There are many different causes of hyperpigmentation, including sun exposure, hormonal influences, medications, and medical conditions. The most common cause of hyperpigmentation is sun exposure. People with fair skin are more prone to hyperpigmentation and age spots. They should use high SPF sunscreen to protect their skin from the sun's harmful rays. They can also use topical medications to help lighten dark spots, such as hydroquinone and azelaic acid. Creams containing steroids and vitamin C are also effective for lightening dark spots.
You have got a milium under your eye. It will heal on its own. You can apply moisturiser and sunscreen.

The mole on your skin is slightly irregular looking. You should be seen in person to make sure it is not skin cancer. It looks like it could be a wart. If it is a wart, you can treat it with liquid nitrogen or salicylic acid.
This is a viral infection. It requires antiviral medication. I am adding a cream for the same to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Avoid scratching.

This looks like tinea versicolor. It is a common yeast infection of the skin, often found in areas with curly or wavy hair. The condition is not considered infectious in the conventional sense. It is usually treated with topical antifungal agents. I am adding a cream for the same to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. You can also take antihistamines on an SOS basis. Keep the area clean. Wash with mild soap and water. Wear loose cotton clothes.

It is a case of common wart. This noncancerous growth appears when your skin is infected with one of the many viruses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) family. If you cut or damage your skin in some way, it's easier for the virus to take hold. That's why people with chronic skin conditions, such as eczema, or who bite their nails or pick at hangnails are prone to getting warts. Warts are highly contagious and are mainly passed by direct skin contact, such as when you pick at your warts and then touch another area of your body. You can also spread them with things like towels or razors that have touched a wart on your body or on someone else's. Most warts are harmless, and you don't need to do anything unless, of course, they're painful or embarrassing. Over-the-counter gels, liquids, and pads with salicylic acid work by peeling away the dead skin cells of the wart to gradually dissolve it. For better results, soak the wart in warm water, then gently sand it with a disposable emery board before you apply the product. Be sure to use a new emery board each time. Be patient, it can take several months. If you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, you should have a doctor take a look before you treat a wart yourself. Cryotherapy, immunotherapy, laser treatment and topical cantharidin are good therapeutic options.

This is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example, low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.
This is a type of eczema. Avoid irritants. Use mild handwash and apply moisturizer and sunscreen.

This is a case of common wart. This noncancerous growth appears when your skin is infected with one of the many viruses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) family. If you cut or damage your skin in some way, it's easier for the virus to take hold. That's why people with chronic skin conditions, such as eczema, or who bite their nails or pick at hangnails are prone to getting warts. Warts are highly contagious and are mainly passed by direct skin contact, such as when you pick at your warts and then touch another area of your body. You can also spread them with things like towels or razors that have touched a wart on your body or on someone else's. Most warts are harmless, and you don't need to do anything unless, of course, they're painful or embarrassing. Over-the-counter gels, liquids, and pads with salicylic acid work by peeling away the dead skin cells of the wart to gradually dissolve it. Cryotherapy, immunotherapy, laser treatment and topical cantharidin are good therapeutic options.

This is a type of eczema. It mostly occurs during change of weather. It can recurr too. Avoid irritant exposure, excessive handwashing, hand sanitizer, vegetable juices, and detergents. Use a mild handwashing soap and apply a good moisturiser multiple times per day. I have added a cream for faster healing, to be applied twice daily for 3 weeks.

It is most a case of trichostasis spinulosa, a benign dermatological syndrome characterized by the presence of numerous fine hair stylic knots in the medullary layer of the scalp. These knots can be due to intralesional inflammation of the hair follicles, trauma, or friction from clothing and accessories. They are more common in people with curly or tightly coiled hair. Trichostasis spinulosa is usually diagnosed clinically and investigation is not necessary for the majority of cases. Treatment of trichostasis spinulosa usually results in improvement in symptoms. Mild cases may be cured by gently detangling the hair or using a topical antifollure/antibacterial product. More severe cases may require surgical excision of the affected hair follicles.
This is eczema. Avoid irritants. Use mild soap anf apply moisturiser. Start giving the cream at night for a month. If it still persists then it may require an excision to remove.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

This is a case of insect bite reaction which is a self limiting immunological reaction to the bites of mosquitoes, fleas, bedbugs, and other insects. The spots remain for days to weeks and can leave postinflammatory pigmentation. Fleas and mites that live on cats and dogs are most often responsible. Wear protective clothing and apply insect repellents to exposed skin to prevent insect bites when outdoors, Insecticides can be used to rid the house. Seek veterinary advice regarding infested animal. Apply topical corticosteroid cream, calamine or menthol lotions and creams and oral antihistamines are used in severe itching.

I need to know whether there was a mole present underneath and whether you have applied something to it. As of now it looks eczematous. I am adding a cream for eczema, to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks, then we can reassess.

This looks like a tick bite. It is very important to remove ticks as soon as possible after being bitten to reduce the risk of disease transmission. Use fine-tipped tweezers to remove the tick entirely. Be sure to grasp the tick head and pull upward with steady, even pressure. Avoid twisting or jerking the tick. After removing the tick, clean the bite area with soap and water. Apply ice to the area to reduce swelling. If you noticed any unusual mark or symptom after being bitten by a tick, consult your doctor. Take antibiotics as prescribed by your doctor to prevent disease.
This looks like it is probably related to the acne lesion. I have added a cream to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Also take an antihistamine if required. Avoid scratching.
This looks like it could be a black line under the nail called a nail fold. It is not dangerous in itself and you don't need to do anything unless it is there due to a recent trauma.

You have shingles, which is a viral infection of the nerves. The symptoms of shingles can be managed with painkillers and antihistamines. You should also apply moisturizer and sunscreen. The rash will heal on its own in about 2 to 3 weeks, but there is a risk of residual rash even after it heals. This is called shingles rash regression (SRR). SRR can be prevented by maintaining good hydration and applying moisturizer and sunscreen.

It is a case of folliculitis, an inflammation of the hair follicles. There are several types of folliculitis, which are often caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi. The most common type of folliculitis is called tinea corporis, which comes from the idea that it is related to ringworm of the ear. However, this is not always the case and tinea corporis is just a type of fungal infection of the skin. Other types of folliculitis include folliculitis impetigo, which is related to the presence of bacteria or yeast; and folliculitis herpetiformis, which is related to the presence of yeast. Treatment of folliculitis involves the use of topical antifungal agents, antibiotics for infection, and sometimes systemic steroids.

This is a type of eczema. It mostly occurs during change of weather. It can recurr too. Avoid irritant exposure, excessive handwashing, hand sanitizer, vegetable juices, and detergents. Use a mild handwashing soap and apply a good moisturiser multiple times per day. I have added a cream for faster healing, to be applied twice daily for 3 weeks.

This looks like a nevus on the scalp. If it is not changing, growing, or bleeding then it is most likely okay to leave. However, if it is doing any of those things then consider seeing your doctor for a possible biopsy removal.
This is eczema. Apply moisturizer. Apply the cream which I have added twice daily for 2 weeks. Take antihistamine on an SOS basis for itching.

This is a type of eczema. It mostly occurs during change of weather. It can recurr too. Avoid irritant exposure, excessive handwashing, hand sanitizer, vegetable juices, and detergents. Use a mild soap for bathing and apply a good moisturiser multiple times per day. I have added a cream for faster healing, to be applied twice daily for 3 weeks.

This looks like a mole only. It is not clear if there is any additional skin tissue present. If it is a mole then it can be treated with either regular mole removal or laser treatment. Regular removal is the safer option.

Most propably this is a case of hormonal acne. Acne is largely a hormonal condition thatâ€™s driven by androgen hormones (testosterone). This typically becomes active during teenage and young adult years. Mild acne can be treated with over-the-counter (OTC) medications, such as gels, soaps, pads, creams, and lotions, that are applied to the skin. Creams and lotions are best for sensitive skin. Alcohol-based gels dry the skin and are better for oily skin. It is advisable to start with the lowest strengths, as some preparations can cause skin irritation, redness, or burning on first use. Topical acne medications include benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, and antibiotics like clindamycin or erythromycin.

It is a case of solar lentigo, a harmless condition that happens on prolonged sun exposure. Examination using dermatoscopy can clarify the diagnosis. Use topical moisturizer containing aloe vera, and use creams containing licorice extract and vitamin C. There are many topical creams available over the counter that you can apply at home to remove sunspots. Look for creams containing glycolic acid, hydroxy acid, or kojic acid. Taking a vitamin E supplement offers protection against sun damage and can improve your skinâ€™s health, especially when taken together with vitamin C. Use high SPF sunscreen to avoid sun damage.
This is likely a fungal infection of the nails. You should keep the nails short and clean. Apply a topical antifungal to help resolve this rash.
This is not infected. This is a reaction to some irritant. I have added a cream to be applied twice daily for 10 days. Apply moisturiser and avoid irritant exposure.

The skin on the feet is peeling. This can happen during and after the treatment of foot acne. The acne lesions can remain active for several months after they have been treated. In some cases, the skin may continue to peel even after the lesions have healed. This can happen if the treatment was too strong for the skin or if the person is using too much moisturizer or sunscreen. To stop the peeling, you can apply a strong moisturizer several times a day and use a high SPF sunscreen. You can also wear socks and shoes with soft soles.

It is not clear based on this blurry photo what this lesion may be. However, if it is new, changing, or you have other lesions then you may need to be seen in person for a biopsy. If it is not new or changing then it may be a cyst and you can watch it. If it is a cyst then it will need to be excised.
This is indeed atrophic scar. It will heal with time. You can apply moisturizer and sunscreen to prevent wrinkles.
This looks like a wound on the leg. It can be due to some trauma or friction. I am adding a cream to be applied twice daily for 10 days. Apply moisturiser and avoid friction.

I need to know whether there is a history of trauma or any irritant application. It can be due to some insect bite or some allergy. I have added a cream to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Also, apply moisturiser and use a mild soap.

I need to know whether there is any history of trauma, infection, or medication reaction. Tissue sample will be taken and sent for histopathology. Meanwhile I am adding a cream, to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Apply moisturiser and use a mild lip balm.

It is a case of urticaria, a self-limiting immunological reaction to drugs, food, bites of mosquitoes, fleas, bedbugs, and other insects. The spots remain for days to weeks and can leave postinflammatory pigmentation. Fleas and mites that live on cats and dogs are often responsible. Wear protective clothing and apply insect repellents to exposed skin to prevent insect bites when outdoors. Insecticides can be used to rid the house. Seek veterinary advice regarding infested animal. Apply topical corticosteroid cream, calamine or menthol lotions and creams and oral antihistamines are used in severe itching.

This looks like it could be a case of inflamed pimple, possibly due to folliculitis or acne. You should try using a topical steroid for a week and if that doesn't help, then you may need to see your doctor to discuss other options.

This looks like it is probably due to dehydration. Make sure you are drinking enough water. If that doesn't help, you may need to have a small piece of the nail removed and have the doctor look at it to make sure there is nothing else going on.

This is acne. It can becomed aggravated due to oily face, hot and humid weather, hormonal fluctuations within the body, and certain foods. Use glycolic acid based cleanser and oil free moisturiser. I am adding anti-acne cream to be applied over pimples at night only. Along with this i have added an antibiotic to be taken twice daily for a month and then we'll review results of the treatment.
